required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Respect for Persons in the Genomics Research Enrollment Process
clinical_study.official_title: Respect for Persons in the Genomics Research Enrollment Process: Incorporating Diverse Experiences and Attitudes

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to integrate an intervention into an ongoing study and evaluate its clinical feasibility and estimated effects on participants' experiences of respect, trust, and willingness to enroll in current and future studies. This intervention will be developed based on preliminary interview and focus group findings. The investigators will integrate the intervention into the study enrollment process of a partner study and measure it with a brief survey. In this feasibility study, the investigators will learn if this intervention can successfully be integrated into a clinical trial, gather preliminary data to determine if it should be tested in a future efficacy study, and estimate sample size for future study. The investigators hypothesize that the intervention will increase perceived respect, trust, and willingness to enroll.

primary_outcome.description: Scores on 4-item Trust in Medical Researchers scale (Hall et al. Measuring Trust in Medical Researchers. Medical Care 2006;44(11):1048-53) among individuals exposed to the intervention versus not exposed. Each question is scored on a 1-5 scale (including one reverse-coded negative question), for a minimum score of 4 and maximum of 20, with higher scores indicating higher trust.

secondary_outcome.description: Participant-reported perception of respect among individuals exposed to the intervention versus not exposed. No validated measures exist for this outcome so it will be assessed with a single item, "I felt respected in this study" (precise wording to be finalized after cognitive testing), scored on a 1-5 scale from "strongly disagree" to "strongly agree," with higher scores indicating higher perceived respect.

Participant-reported willingness to enroll in future studies among individuals exposed to the intervention versus not exposed. No validated measures exist for this outcome so it will be assessed with a single item, "I would be willing to join another study in the future" (precise wording to be finalized after cognitive testing), scored on a 1-5 scale from "strongly disagree" to "strongly agree," with higher scores indicating greater willingness to enroll.
Enrollment rates of individuals exposed to intervention or not

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through partner study completion, up to 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Retention rates of individuals exposed to intervention or not

arm_group.description: Individuals in this arm will go through the partner study's standard recruitment and consent process
Individuals in this arm will be exposed to our intervention during the partner study's recruitment and consent process

intervention.description: This intervention will be designed based on outcomes from interviews and focus groups that will identify specific actions with the potential to demonstrate respect in the recruitment and consent process. Potential interventions include but are not limited to: research staff training, messaging related to inclusivity, messaging related to voluntariness, additional ethical oversight or other autonomy protections, and guidelines for researchers about study design.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult capable of providing consent for oneself
- Goes through enrollment process for partner study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to complete brief survey
